Problem:
Consider an electrical circuit consisting of a linear resistor and a capacitor. The charging of the capacitor over time t is described by the differential equation \\(\\frac{dV}{dt} = -\\frac{1}{RC}(V-V_0)\\), where V is the voltage across the capacitor, R is the resistance, C is the capacitance, and \\(V_0\\) is the constant input voltage. To analyze the system, we explore the influence of a sinusoidal signal \\(A \\sin(\\omega t)\\) superimposed on the input voltage \\(V_0\\).

Suppose at time \\(t_1\\), an intervention adjusts the resistance R in the circuit. Will the resultant voltage \\(V(T)\\) for T > t_1 be independent of the sinusoidal amplitude A added at t = 0?
Explanation: Changing the resistance alters the RC time constant, which affects how the circuit responds both to the constant voltage \\(V_0\\) and the sinusoidal part. Thus, the output voltage \\(V(T)\\) depends on both the sine wave amplitude A and the new resistance value.
